details.purpose: To capture Hip arthroplasty details consistent with the National Arthroplasty Registry of Slovenia (RES).

template_id.value: Slovenia RES Primary Hip Arthroplasty Report

template.concept: Slovenia RES Primary Hip Arthroplasty Report

term_definitions.items: Identifiers of a person compliant with Slovenia requirements
Personal name compliant with European ISA standard.

Multiple family names, such as are commonly found in Hispanic countries, are recorded in the single Family Name field so that, for example, Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra's Family Name would be recorded as "de Cervantes Saavedra.
A family name is usually shared by members of a family. This attribute also carries prefixes or suffixes which are part of the Family Name, e.g. “de Boer”, “van de Putte”, “von und zu Orlow”.
All given names are ordered in one field so that, for example, the Given Name for Johan Sebastian Bach is 'Johan Sebastian.'

A given name, or multiple given names, are the denominator(s) that identify an individual within a family. These are given to a person by his or her parents at birth or may be legally recognised as 'given names' through a formal process.
There is no granularity for birth name - the full name should be recorded in a single field.
Name given to the person at birth.

The full name (fullName) property contains the complete name of a person as one string. In addition to the content of given name, family name and, in some systems, patronymic name, this can carry additional parts of a person’s name such as titles, middle names or suffixes like “the third” or names which are neither a given nor a family name.

Note that patronymic names refer to a father's given name, not the family name inherited from the mother and father as is the case in countries such as Spain and Portugal. Again referring to the example of Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra's, the patronymic name element would be unused.

Patronymic names are important in some countries. Iceland does not have a concept of 'family name' in the way that many other European countries do, for example. Erik Magnusson and Erika Magnusdottir are siblings, both offspring of Mangnus, irrespective of his patronymic name. In Bulgaria and Russia, patronymic names are in every day usage, for example, the Sergeyevich in 'Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev.'
Any name by which an individual is known other than their full name.
Ther current administrative gender of the person.
The sex of the person at birth.
Whether the patient is alive or dead.
The age of the person. This may be calculated.
Details of person's death aligned with PARENT Common Data Elements for registry use.
The date of the subject's death.
Was the death due to the primary diagnosis?
Identifiable details of a person compliant with European ISA standard.
Contact details for the person e.g telephone numbers, email etc.
Personal name compliant with European ISA standard.

Multiple family names, such as are commonly found in Hispanic countries, are recorded in the single Family Name field so that, for example, Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra's Family Name would be recorded as "de Cervantes Saavedra.
A family name is usually shared by members of a family. This attribute also carries prefixes or suffixes which are part of the Family Name, e.g. “de Boer”, “van de Putte”, “von und zu Orlow”.
All given names are ordered in one field so that, for example, the Given Name for Johan Sebastian Bach is 'Johan Sebastian.'

A given name, or multiple given names, are the denominator(s) that identify an individual within a family. These are given to a person by his or her parents at birth or may be legally recognised as 'given names' through a formal process.
There is no granularity for birth name - the full name should be recorded in a single field.
Name given to the person at birth.

The full name (fullName) property contains the complete name of a person as one string. In addition to the content of given name, family name and, in some systems, patronymic name, this can carry additional parts of a person’s name such as titles, middle names or suffixes like “the third” or names which are neither a given nor a family name.

Note that patronymic names refer to a father's given name, not the family name inherited from the mother and father as is the case in countries such as Spain and Portugal. Again referring to the example of Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra's, the patronymic name element would be unused.

Patronymic names are important in some countries. Iceland does not have a concept of 'family name' in the way that many other European countries do, for example. Erik Magnusson and Erika Magnusdottir are siblings, both offspring of Mangnus, irrespective of his patronymic name. In Bulgaria and Russia, patronymic names are in every day usage, for example, the Sergeyevich in 'Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev.'
Any name by which an individual is known other than their full name.
Address details compliant with European ISA Standard.
The complete address written as a string, with or without formatting.
An address component that represents the name of a passage or way through from one location to another. A thoroughfare is not necessarily a road, it might be a waterway or some other feature.
For an address such as "Flat 3, 17 Bridge Street", the locator is "flat 3, 17."
this is the building number, apartment number, etc.
The name of the property or complex, of the building or part of the building, or the name of a room inside a building.
The key postal division of the address, usually the city.
The region of the address, usually a county, state or other such area that typically encompasses several localities.
The uppermost administrative unit for the address, almost always a country.
The post code (a.k.a postal code, zip code etc).
A globally unique identifier for each instance of an address.
The locator name could be the name of the property or complex, of the building or part of the building, or it could be the name of a room inside a building.
Details of a healthcare provider organisation.
The unique identifier of the organisation.
The name of a specific department within the organisation.
The identifier of a specific department.
Contact details for the heathcare worker.
Record details about an anatomical location.
Named anatomical location - ideally would be coded where possible.
Specify lateraility of the anatomical location.
Qualifier to identify which direction the anatomical location is in relation to the identified landmark.
Relative location medial to the landmark.
Relative location lateral to the landmark.
Relative location superior to the landmark.
Relative location inferior to the landmark.
In the sagittal plane passing through the midline of the body.
Relative location anterior to the landmark.
Relative location posterior to the landmark.
Relative location inferior and lateral to the landmark.
Relative location superior and lateral to the landmark.
Relative location inferior and medial to the landmark.
Relative location superior and medial to the landmark.

Qualifiers to identify non-specific location eg 5cm (distance) inferior (aspect) to the tibial tuberosity (landmark). There may be more than one relative location required to provide a cross reference.
Identified anatomical landmark from which to specify relative anatomical location.
Distance of location from the identified landmark.
Line describing the position of a vertical anatomical plane in the body.
In the sagittal plane passing through mid-clavical.
In the coronal plane passing through mid-axilla.
In the sagittal plane passing through mid-scapula.
Identify the specific anatomical site out of multiple eg tenth rib; fourth vertebra; second toe.
Ordinal position 1 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 2 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 3 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 4 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 5 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 6 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 7 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 8 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 9 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 10 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 11 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 12 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 13 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 14 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 15 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 16 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 17 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 18 of an anatomical location.
Image or images used to identify a location.
Description of any visual markings used to orientate the viewer e.g external reference points, special sutures, ink markings.
Address details compliant with European ISA Standard.
The complete address written as a string, with or without formatting.
An address component that represents the name of a passage or way through from one location to another. A thoroughfare is not necessarily a road, it might be a waterway or some other feature.
For an address such as "Flat 3, 17 Bridge Street", the locator is "flat 3, 17."
this is the building number, apartment number, etc.
The name of the property or complex, of the building or part of the building, or the name of a room inside a building.
The key postal division of the address, usually the city.
The region of the address, usually a county, state or other such area that typically encompasses several localities.
The uppermost administrative unit for the address, almost always a country.
The post code (a.k.a postal code, zip code etc).
A globally unique identifier for each instance of an address.
The locator name could be the name of the property or complex, of the building or part of the building, or it could be the name of a room inside a building.
Details of a healthcare provider organisation.
The unique identifier of the organisation.
The name of a specific department within the organisation.
The identifier of a specific department.
A clinical activity that has been carried out for therapeutic or diagnostic purposes.
Details of procedures prior to primary hip arthroplasty.
Detailed structure describing the procedure carried out, including preparation and details about the method and equipment/devices used.
Was the procedure ultimately unsuccessful? True if unsuccessful.
Details about any complication arising from the procedure.
Multimedia representation of the procedure, including images.
The reason or indication for the procedure.
An unplanned event prior to or related to the procedure, which may affect its execution e.g patient self-removed cannula.
The number of failed attempts to perform the procedure.

Record information about unplanned or unexpected activities that needed to be done during the procedure. Record the name of the task and a description within this archetype, but detail should be recorded in specific linked INSTRUCTION or ACTION archetypes.
Description of additional task performed during the procedure.
Link to a detailed record of the additional task.
Narrative description about the procedure carried out.
Details about the anatomical site of procedure.
Identification of specific method or technique used for procedure.
Name of additional task performed during the procedure.
The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service.
Was this procedure performed as an emergency? True if Yes.
Generic, positive statement/s that need to be recorded as clinically excluded from the health record at a specific point in time.
Positive statement/s about procedures that need to be recorded as clinically excluded from the health record at a specific point in time.

Use to capture any information that is needed to be positively recorded as being excluded within the record. The statement can support recording global statements or statements about a specified object. See specialisations for Medications, Adverse Reactions, Problem/Diagnosis and Procedures as common examples that have been explicitly modelled.
The statement about an exclusion in the health record.
For example: "No known operations or significant procedures" or "No previous" (appendicectomy).
A statement about exclusion of procedures performed in the health record.
Identification of the specific object/s to which the Exclusion Statement applies.
Coding of the Procedure with a terminology is desirable, where possible.
Identification of the procedures to which the Exclusion Statement applies.
The date at which the exclusion was last clinically asserted, affirmed or confirmed.
Additional narrative about the Exclusion not captured in other fields.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.

Record of status and details of informed consent from a patient (or patient's agent) for a proposed procedure, trial or other healthcare-related activity (including treatments and investigations), based upon a clear appreciation and understanding of the facts, implications, and possible future consequences by the patient or patient's agent.
Identification of the procedure, clinical trial or healthcare-related activity (including correct side/correct site, where appropriate) against which the consent status and details are recorded.
For example: intent/purpose; anaesthetic details; disclosure of material risks; and proposed benefits discussed.
Additional structured details about the procedure/trial/activity itself or additional structured consent details.
Form of the consent sought or provided.
Format of the consent is written.
Format of the consent is verbal.
For example, the reason for 'consent refused' or 'consent withdrawn'.
Reason that the care pathway step for the identified procedure, clinical trial or healthcare-related activity was carried out.
Date, and optional time, when validity of the informed consent becomes active.
Date, and optional time, when validity of the informed consent ceased.
Details of any qualifications or exemptions to the informed consent.
Narrative description of the informed consent required or recorded prior to performing the proposed procedure, clinical trial or healthcare-related activity.
For example, audio of consent being requested or image of written consent obtained.
Need for informed consent is identified.
Informed consent has been requested from the patient or patient's agent, but no response has been received.
Informed consent has been provided by the patient or patient's agent.
In response to a request for informed consent, it has been refused by patient or patient's agent.
Following initial provision of informed consent, it has been withrawn by the patient or patient's agent.
Intent to request informed consent has been cancelled, prior to requesting consent from patient or patient's agent..
Intent to request informed consent has been postponed.
Informed consent was not obtainable from either the patient or patient's advocate.
Informed consent has been provided by the patient or patient's agent and the activity is now complete.
Identification of the consent form or document used.
Date when consent status is due for review.
An appointment has been scheduled to request consent.
Insert archetyped demographic details in this SLOT if it is not possible to use other_participations.
Details about the healthcare provider who is requesting or recording the consent.
Insert archetyped demographic details in this SLOT if it is not possible to use other_participations.
Details about the subject (or subject's agent) who is being requested for, or providing, the consent for the procedure, clinical trial or healthcare-related activity.
Narrative description of the procedure, clinical trial or healthcare-related activity.
Description of the intent of the procedure, clinical trial or healthcare-related activity.
For example, the name of the form.
Identification of the information made available.
Details about Patient Information made available to the subject or subject's agent.
Digital representation of the Patient Information made available.
Narrative description of the patient information made available.
Height, or body length, is measured from crown of head to sole of foot. Height is measured with the individual in a standing position and body length in a recumbent position.
Any timed measurement of height or body length.
The length of the body from crown of head to sole of foot.
Description of the device used to measure height or body length.
Height is measured standing on both feet with weight distributed evenly, heels together and both buttocks and heels in contact with a vertical back board.
Comment about the measurement of body height/length.
Record any issues or factors that may impact on the measurement of body height/length eg noting of amputation.
Length is measured in a fully extended, recumbent position with the pelvis flat, legs extended and feet flexed.
Measurement of the body weight of an individual.
Description of the state of dress of the person at the time of weighing.
Clothing which may add significantly to weight, including shoes.
Clothing which will not add to weight significantly.
Wearing only a nappy - can add significant weight.
Comment about the measurement of weight.
Record any issues or factors that may impact on the measurement of body weight eg timing in menstrual cycle, timing of recent bowel motion or noting of amputation.
The result of the Harris Hip Score.
Grading derived from Harris Hip score.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Additional hip procedure details to align with Valdoltra hospital hip registry.
Systemic antibiotic prophylaxis was given to the patient.
Systemic antibiotic prophylaxis was not given to the patient.
The duration of the hip procedure.
Additional details of hip arthropasty component.
The name of the cement used.
The name of the coating used.
True if antibiotics/antibacterials were added to the cement.
The material used in the manufacture of the arthroplasty component.
Issues identified or excluded that may have a safety impact e.g MRI risk.
The tested MRI Tesla safety level.

An instrument, apparatus, implant, material or similar, used in the provision of healthcare. In this context, a medical device includes a broad range of devices which act through a variety of physical, mechanical, thermal or similar means but specifically excludes devices which act through medicinal means such as pharmacological, metabolic or immunological methods. The scope is inclusive of disposable devices as well as durable or persisting devices that require tracking, maintenance activities or regular calibration, recognising that each type of device has specific data recording requirements.

This data element will capture the term, phrase or category used in clinical practice. For example: <brand name><machine> (XYZ Audiometer); <size> <brand name> <intravenous catheter> (14G Jelco IV catheter); or <brand name/type> <implant>. With specific examples.
Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible, although this may be local and depending on local supplies available.
Identification of the medical device, preferably by a common name, a formal fully descriptive name or, if required, by class or category of device.
Narrative description of the medical device.

Not applicable if a category is already recorded in 'Device name'. Example: if the 'Device' is named as a 'urinary catheter'; the 'Type' may be recorded as 'indwelling' or 'condom'.Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible. This may include use of GTIN or EAN numbers.
The category or kind of device.
The number assigned by the manufacturer which identifies a group of items manufactured at the same time, usually found on the label or packaging material.
This date usually applies only to single use or disposable devices.
Date after which the device/product is no longer fit for use, usually found on the device itself or printed on the accompanying packaging.
Additional narrative about the device not captured in other fields.
Further details about specific properties about the medical device.
Additional structured informations about identified components of the device.
For example: Owner, Contact details, Location, Network address, Date due for replacement, Calibration details etc.
Further details about management and maintenance of the device.
Number assigned by the manufacturer which can be found on the device, and should be specific to each device., its label, or accompanying packaging.
Often fixed to the device as a barcode.
A numeric or alphanumeric string that is associated with this device within a given system.
The exact number assigned by the manufacturer, as it appears in the manufacturer's catalogue, device labeling, or accompanying packaging.
The exact model number assigned by the manufacturer and found on the device label or accompanying packaging.
Coding of the name of the identifier with a coding system is desirable, if available.
Unspecified identifier, which can be further specified in a template or at run time.

When the medical device is an actual software application, record the version of the software using this data element. When the medical device has multiple software applications embedded within it, record each software component in a separate CLUSTER archetype within the Components SLOT - either as a nested instance of another CLUSTER.device archetype or using a CLUSTER archetype designed specifically for recording software details (but not yet available at time of this archetype development).
Identification of the version of software being used in the medical device.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: a technical diagram of a device, or a digital image.

An instrument, apparatus, implant, material or similar, used in the provision of healthcare. In this context, a medical device includes a broad range of devices which act through a variety of physical, mechanical, thermal or similar means but specifically excludes devices which act through medicinal means such as pharmacological, metabolic or immunological methods. The scope is inclusive of disposable devices as well as durable or persisting devices that require tracking, maintenance activities or regular calibration, recognising that each type of device has specific data recording requirements.

This data element will capture the term, phrase or category used in clinical practice. For example: <brand name><machine> (XYZ Audiometer); <size> <brand name> <intravenous catheter> (14G Jelco IV catheter); or <brand name/type> <implant>. With specific examples.
Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible, although this may be local and depending on local supplies available.
Identification of the medical device, preferably by a common name, a formal fully descriptive name or, if required, by class or category of device.
Narrative description of the medical device.

Not applicable if a category is already recorded in 'Device name'. Example: if the 'Device' is named as a 'urinary catheter'; the 'Type' may be recorded as 'indwelling' or 'condom'.Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible. This may include use of GTIN or EAN numbers.
The category or kind of device.
The number assigned by the manufacturer which identifies a group of items manufactured at the same time, usually found on the label or packaging material.
This date usually applies only to single use or disposable devices.
Date after which the device/product is no longer fit for use, usually found on the device itself or printed on the accompanying packaging.
Additional narrative about the device not captured in other fields.
Further details about specific properties about the medical device.
Additional structured informations about identified components of the device.
For example: Owner, Contact details, Location, Network address, Date due for replacement, Calibration details etc.
Further details about management and maintenance of the device.
Number assigned by the manufacturer which can be found on the device, and should be specific to each device., its label, or accompanying packaging.
Often fixed to the device as a barcode.
A numeric or alphanumeric string that is associated with this device within a given system.
The exact number assigned by the manufacturer, as it appears in the manufacturer's catalogue, device labeling, or accompanying packaging.
The exact model number assigned by the manufacturer and found on the device label or accompanying packaging.
Coding of the name of the identifier with a coding system is desirable, if available.
Unspecified identifier, which can be further specified in a template or at run time.

When the medical device is an actual software application, record the version of the software using this data element. When the medical device has multiple software applications embedded within it, record each software component in a separate CLUSTER archetype within the Components SLOT - either as a nested instance of another CLUSTER.device archetype or using a CLUSTER archetype designed specifically for recording software details (but not yet available at time of this archetype development).
Identification of the version of software being used in the medical device.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: a technical diagram of a device, or a digital image.

ICD codes: M05 M06 M07* M08 M09* M10 M11 M45
Rheumatoid Arthritis, other arthritis and anylosing spondyilitis
ICD codes M00 M01* M15 M16.6 M16.7 M16.9 M19 M86
A clinical activity that has been carried out for therapeutic or diagnostic purposes.
Details of primary hip arthroplasty constrined to align with Slovenian RES register.
Detailed structure describing the procedure carried out, including preparation and details about the method and equipment/devices used.

Details about any complication arising from the procedure.
Multimedia representation of the procedure, including images.
The reason or indication for the procedure.

template_id.value: Slovenia RES Primary Hip Arthroplasty Report

term_definitions.items: Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.
e.g. Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
